MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Closed Circuit Television Systems.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: when a closed circuit television system will be installed in Dún Laoghaire, County Dublin.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: The advisory committee that was established by the Garda Commissioner to examine CCTV systems as an aid to policing and to evaluate each application has received in excess of 31 applications for the installation of Garda CCTV systems, including one from Dún Laoghaire. At present six locations have been prioritised for the installation of Garda CCTV systems as an aid to policing. The prioritised locations are as follows: Bray, Cork, Dublin South Central, Dundalk, Finglas and Limerick. The remaining applications, including Dún Laoghaire, are still under consideration by the committee and it is anticipated that further systems will be scheduled in due course as staffing and budgetary resources permit.

Each of the applications currently under consideration will be prioritised with regard to the respective levels of crime in the locations in question and the likely impact of a Garda CCTV system on same. Applications are also evaluated from a technical and telecommunications perspective. It is also only fair to state in this regard that the commitment to existing schemes, as well as those prioritised by the advisory committee, limits the scope for the extension of Garda CCTV systems to other areas at the present time.

Funding for Garda CCTV systems is normally provided jointly by local community interests and my Department. It has been the experience of the Garda authorities that the cost of an efficient and effective CCTV system is, on average, £20,000 to £25,000 per camera. Each application submitted must also be prepared in co-operation with the local Garda district and divisional officers and receive their full support.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will appoint a full-time secretary to each of St. Joseph's senior and junior schools in Ballymun, Dublin 11, which currently have a total complement of 44 teachers and cater for a population of 520 pupils.

Qst.hpid: Mr. P. Carey Mr. P. Carey
Qst.Quest: his views on whether a separate secretary should be appointed to St Joseph's senior and junior schools, Balcurris Road, Ballymun, Dublin 11 in view of the fact that there is a total of 44 teachers who cater for 520 pupils and these schools have the most severe of social and educational needs; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 338 and 352 together.
My Department provides funding towards the cost of secretarial services in primary schools under two separate schemes.

MainHeading.P: Under the scheme for the employment of secretaries which was introduced in 1978, my Department meets the full cost of salary and employer's PRSI. This is the scheme under which St. Joseph's junior school and St. Joseph's senior school qualified for the shared secretary arrangement. However this scheme is being phased out as posts become vacant and there is no provision for the appointment of full-time secretaries in posts which are being shared. In the circumstances it will not be possible to sanction the appointment of an additional full-time secretary to either school.

Under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, a second scheme was introduced in 1992 whereby my Department provides additional capitation grants for primary schools towards the cost of secretarial services.

Should the existing shared post fall vacant, my Department will provide both schools with a grant of £15 per pupil per annum towards the cost of secretarial services (subject to a maximum grant of £7,500 to each school) in accordance with the current terms of the PESP scheme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if he will introduce a means tested payment for multiple births where these students are entering third level education in view of the fact that there are now means tested payments at age four entering primary level and age 12 entering secondary level; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that the payments referred to by the Deputy are universal payments made by the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs under the child benefit scheme.

The third level student support schemes operated under the aegis of my Department provide a means tested maintenance grant to eligible students who are pursuing approved third level courses. To qualify the candidate's reckonable income and that of his or her parents or guardians, where applicable, must be below the relevant income limit, which varies for the level of grant and in relation to the number of dependent children in the family. Different limits apply where there are less than four dependent children, between four and seven dependent children, and eight or more dependent children. Furthermore, where there are two or more children attending full-time third level education or other specified courses, the relevant income limits are increased by £2,060 where there are two such children, £4,120 for three children and so on, by increments of £2,060.
In these circumstances, I have no plans to introduce a payment along the lines suggested by the Deputy.

A study of educational disadvantage conducted by the Combat Poverty Agency and the Education Research Centre in 1996 concluded that disadvantaged area status should be confined to 16 per cent of the school-going population. Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the average value under each of the criteria for deciding designation as disad vantaged in respect of the most recent 20 schools granted disadvantaged status, that is the percentage with medical cards, lone parents and so on.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that the Deputy is referring to the last general expansion of the disadvantaged areas scheme both at primary level and second level. This expansion took place in 1994 when an additional 54 schools were included in the scheme at primary level and 55 schools at second level.

On that occasion applicant schools were assessed as to priority of need by reference to a range of criteria which had been agreed between the Department, schools' management and the teacher unions. At primary level, the criteria in question took account of such factors as the levels of unemployment, local authority housing and rented accommodation occupancy and medical card holding among the families of the pupils concerned. The total points scored by schools under the above headings were then weighted by a factor which took account of the prevailing pupil teacher ratios among the applicant schools. At second level, account was also taken of rural disadvantage, lone parent households, literacy-numeracy difficulties and lack of formal educational qualifications.

At primary level the average percentage of pupils, in the lowest scoring 20 schools of the 54 that were added to the scheme in 1994, whose parents were included in the relevant categories, was as follows: level of unemployment – 52 per cent; local authority housing – 45 per cent; rented accommodation occupancy – 7 per cent and medical card holding – 55 per cent.

At second level the relevant percentages were as follows: level of unemployment – 67 per cent; local housing – 59 per cent; medical card holding – 70 per cent; rural disadvantage – 41 per cent; lone parent households – 17 per cent; literacy-numeracy – 50 per cent and formal education qualifications – 12 per cent.

Qst.Quest: if persons (details supplied) will be allowed to change the examination centre for their leaving certificate in view of the fact that there is no scheduled public transport or any person in the home with transport to take them to the examination centre; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The administration of State examinations annually, catering for about 140,000 candidates in over 4,500 examination centres, is a major logistical challenge. The task would become impossible to administer if students having been registered to take the examination in one school were free to subsequently take the examinations in another school. The only reasonable position that the Department can adopt is that once entered by a particular school a student must take his-her examinations in a centre in that school. The Department can exercise some flexibility in exceptional circumstances, e.g., illness.

In relation to transport, the expectation is that the arrangements for transport to and from the school that apply at other times during the school year should also apply during the examination period.

In the case of the candidates referred to by the Deputy, my Department received a request on 2 February 1999 for a change of examination centre. From the information available to the Department the circumstances applying in this case are not exceptional and the position of the candidates concerned is similar to that of many other students.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 382, 388, 389, 390 and 391 together.

The vocational training opportunities scheme was established to enable long-term unemployed people to return to education and training programmes, with a view to enhancing their employability, without losing their social welfare entitlements. Participants on the scheme are paid a training allowance at least equal to their social welfare entitlement had they remained on the live register. They also retain their secondary benefit entitlements, such as rent allowances, butter and fuel vouchers. In addition, they are paid a travel allowance, if they reside more than three miles from the centre, and meal allowance.

The programme, which is administered by the Vocational Education Committees, is subject to constant review by my Department in conjunction with vocational education committees. The regulations governing it are amended when deemed appropriate. Recent amendments to the regulations included: the equalisation of allowances payable to VTOS participants with these payable to participants in the back to education scheme of the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs; and the removal of the participation limit of 10 per cent maximum for lone parents, disabled people and spouses.
A study is at present being undertaken on how to make the scheme more effective in reaching older long-term unemployed people.

The annual cost of the VTOS scheme is of the order of £25 million, which is used to pay training allowances, teachers' pay, books and materials. Expenditure on the scheme is broken down into pay and non-pay. Pay comprises the salaries of teachers and administrative costs. Non-pay includes training allowances, books, equipment, materials and overheads.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of schools and pupils involved in special programmes to give structures support to pupils making the transition from primary to secondary level education; and the estimated costs of these programmes.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Second level schools generally liaise closely with their primary feeder schools in relation to pupil transfers. Most second level schools organise open days for senior primary pupils and their parents to visit the schools. This arrangement enables the primary pupils and their parents to familiarise themselves with the schools and the programmes on offer and can be of great assistance in easing transition from first to second level.

There is a particular need to encourage the transition from primary to second level of pupils from disadvantaged areas. This is best achieved by ensuring that such pupils and their parents have developed, during their period in the primary system, an appreciation of the importance of continued education to their children's long-term development.

Children attending primary schools in disadvantaged areas are supported by a range of special programmes, including: the disadvantaged areas scheme, which currently covers an estimated 75,800 primary school pupils in 318 schools and involves the allocation of 294 concessionary teachers posts and special capitation funding of £2.3 million per annum; the home-school-community liaison scheme, which currently covers over 58,000 pupils in 225 primary schools and involves the allocation of 133 locally based co-ordinators working with parents and schools in the selected areas; the breaking the cycle of disadvantage initiative, which currently covers approximately 14,000 pupils in 156 schools and involves a special allocation of 121 teachers and special funding of approximately £700,000 per annum; the eight to 15 year old early school leavers programme which is targeted on approximately 2,000 pupils in 78 schools in 14 selected projected areas. A total of £3.62 million is being made available to this programme over the next two years.

All of these programmes are targeted at supporting the participation of disadvantaged children in the primary system and fostering the development of an appreciation of the value of continued participation in the education system.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Enrolments.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if he will indicate the number of schools and pupils in each of the secondary voluntary, VEC and community comprehensive schools; the number of schools and pupils designated disadvantaged and the teachers allocated; the number of schools and pupils with home school community liaison teachers and the number of teachers involved; the number of schools and pupils with remedial teachers and the number of teachers involved; the number of schools and pupils with teacher counsellors and the number of teachers involved; and the number of schools and pupils with guidance counsellors and the number of guidance counsellors involved.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The numbers of schools and enrolments as at end September 1998 are as follows:

MainHeading.P: Two hundred and nine disadvantaged posts have been allocated to 190 second level schools. The total enrolment in these schools is approximately 98,700.

There are 85 second level schools, with a total enrolment of approximately 46,000 pupils, participating in the home-school-community liaison scheme. There are 84 co-ordinators employed in these schools.
Three hundred and fifty ex-quota remedial posts have been allocated at second level. The total enrolment in the schools which have access to an ex-quota remedial service is approximately 217,100.

All schools in the free education scheme have an ex-quota allocation in respect of guidance. The allocation to individual schools varies depending on the enrolment in the school. A total of 567 wholetime teacher equivalents have been allocated in respect of guidance in the current school year.
There are no teacher counsellors allocated at second level.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Youthreach Programmes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of persons in youthreach over the past ten years; and the total cost of youthreach distinguishing income support from programme provision over the past ten years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number in youthreach at foundation and progression levels.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the position of graduates from youthreach one year after they complete participation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the proportion of those completing youthreach who receive certification and the certification achieved.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: cation and Science the proportion of entrants to youthreach who have no qualifications or have junior or leaving certificates.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the classification by age of youthreach participants.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 396, 397, 398, 399, 400 and 401 together.

The youthreach programme was introduced as a joint initiative by FÁS and the vocational education committees in 1989, to provide integrated education, vocational training and work experience for young people in the 15-18 year age group who had left school with either no qualifications or minimal qualifications.

The numbers and cost of the programme in the VEC sector are set out in the following table. The figures up to the end of 1997 do not include training allowances paid to participants, as these were paid by FÁS up to 6 April 1998. The 1998 outlay on training allowances is for part of the year only.

MainHeading.P: *Includes £3,643,166 allowances from 6 April 1998.

A prescriptive approach as to the numbers on foundation and progression level was not adopted at central level, in order to ensure that local centres would have the maximum flexibility to respond to local need. The actual take-up of trainees on foundation and progression level is currently being gathered and will be forwarded to the Deputy as soon as it is available. Of those who complete youthreach, 70.6 per cent enter employment or further education or training. All youthreach trainees avail of certification options ranging from subjects in the junior certificate to City and Guilds, RSA and other providers, and certification from the National Council for Vocational Awards. NCVA certification at foundation level was implemented nationally with effect from September 1997, and level 1 will be implemented nationally with effect from March 1999. Registrations and in-service training took place for this in 1998. The NCVA has an agreement with FÁS which provides for mutual recognition for progression purposes of the FÁS integrated assessment system foundation certificate and the NCVA foundation certificate. In addition, a number of youthreach centres are pursuing options under the leaving cert applied programme. In the VEC sector in 1977, 29 per cent of youthreach trainees had some form of junior cycle qualification on entering the programme, but this was usually less than five grade Ds. The remainder had left school with no qualifications.
Twenty seven per cent of youthreach trainees are aged 15, 34 per cent are 16, 24 per cent are 17, and 15 per cent are 18 years or over.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of people involved in community training workshops over the past ten years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the position of those who have completed community training workshops one year afterwards.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the age profile and qualifications at entry of community training workshop participants.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the profile of certification achieved by community training workshop participation on completion.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 402, 403, 404 and 405 together.

Community training workshops are funded on a contract basis by FÁS, and the numbers, outcomes from the programme, qualifications on entry and certification options available are matters for the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment, to whom identical questions have been directed. The role of my Department in the matter is to allocate teaching hours through the vocational education committees as extra supports for participants with literacy and numeracy difficulties.
